head.title: Transparent Thin-Film Silicon Solar Cells for Indoor Light Harvesting with Conversion Efficiencies of 36% without Photodegradation | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Transparent Thin-Film Silicon Solar Cells for Indoor Light Harvesting with Conversion Efficiencies of 36% without Photodegradation

With the development of the Internet of Things (IoT), indoor photovoltaics are attracting considerable interest owing to their potential to benefit various IoT-related fields. Therefore, this study investigates the use of transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells for a broad range of applications, including indoor light harvesting. High-gap triple layers were employed in the a-Si:H solar cells to obtain a high shunt resistance and high short-circuit current, JSC, and open-circuit voltage, VOC, under indoor illumination. Additionally, multiple color-adjusting layers were added without noticeable costs to the conversion efficiency. The maximum efficiency of 36.0% was obtained at a transmittance of 20.44% under white LED light (3000 lx and 0.92 mW cm–2). Furthermore, the fabricated transparent solar cells show excellent long-term performance, sustaining over 99% of original efficiency under continuous indoor light illumination for 200 h. These cells could accelerate the progress of energy harvesting in IoT applications and facilitate the construction of integrated photovoltaics.

div.p:
With the development of the Internet of Things (IoT), indoor photovoltaics are attracting considerable interest owing to their potential to benefit various IoT-related fields. Therefore, this study investigates the use of transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells for a broad range of applications, including indoor light harvesting. High-gap triple layers were employed in the a-Si:H solar cells to obtain a high shunt resistance and high short-circuit current,
J
SC
, and open-circuit voltage,
V
OC
, under indoor illumination. Additionally, multiple color-adjusting layers were added without noticeable costs to the conversion efficiency. The maximum efficiency of 36.0% was obtained at a transmittance of 20.44% under white LED light (3000 lx and 0.92 mW cm
–2
). Furthermore, the fabricated transparent solar cells show excellent long-term performance, sustaining over 99% of original efficiency under continuous indoor light illumination for 200 h. These cells could accelerate the progress of energy harvesting in IoT applications and facilitate the construction of integrated photovoltaics.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
With the advent of self-contained low-power indoor electronic devices with wireless internet connections, the new internet of things (IoT) industry is forecasted to include tens of billions of connected devices by 2020.
(1−4)
In many IoT applications, conventional batteries are extremely large compared with the tiny devices, and even if the product is large enough to support them, the need to periodically replace batteries is inconvenient and expensive. Therefore, technologies that can drive these electronic devices using only energy that is available indoors, without spare batteries or electric wires, are highly desirable.

Previous studies of available power-generating devices have found that indoor photovoltaics (PVs) with high energy densities and relatively large output voltages are the most suitable energy sources in indoor lighting environments.
(5)
As shown in
Figure
1
a, power generation using indoor lighting can drive various electronic devices across a wide range of power requirements, from 10 nW to 10 W. In addition, as the prospects for the use of transparent electronic devices gradually expand, demand for transparent power sources will also increase; then, indoor PV could be applied to various transparent products including windows, displays, mobile communication devices, and various wireless sensors, as shown in
Figure
1
b.
(6,7)

div.p: Figure 1. Applications for indoor PVs. (a) Power requirements for various electronic devices used in indoor environments, (b) a future house with devices that may be transparent (smart watch and cell phone displays, windows, etc.) or opaque (fire alarms, toothbrush sterilizers, etc.), and (c) comparison of the emission spectra of an AM1.5G solar simulator with commercial cool and warm white light-emitting diode (LED) lamps.

div.div:
As the light spectra of white LEDs are significantly different from the solar spectrum [air mass (AM) 1.5 Global (G), shown in
Figure
1
c], commercially available crystalline silicon solar cells with power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) higher than 20% under AM1.5G illumination exhibit efficiencies of only 5% or less when operated under typical indoor illumination.
(8,9)
Therefore, to obtain a high PCE in these conditions, the cell structure must be tailored specifically for indoor light spectra. Although indoor light sources such as LEDs, incandescent lights, and fluorescent lamps have only 0.2–1.0% of the power of outdoor light,
(10,11)
solar cells operating under indoor light can generate electrical power continuously, including through the night, and should be a useful energy source for low-power devices.

To date, organic solar cells,
(12−19)
dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs),
(20−26)
perovskite solar cells,
(10,27−29)
and silicon-based solar cells
(30−35)
have been explored with the aim of achieving a high PCE for energy harvesting from indoor lighting. Among these, a DSSC has exhibited a high PCE of 28.9%,
(25)
and a perovskite solar cell has shown the highest PCE of 36.2%
(29)
under fluorescent lamps with illuminations of 1000 lx. Nevertheless, these technologies have shown critical disadvantages such as instability, lack of durability, electrolyte leakage, and/or toxic chemical components containing lead, and these limitations must be overcome before commercialization can progress. Moreover, few studies of indoor PV have employed transparent solar cells, which will be urgently required for emerging indoor applications, and PCEs in existing transparent cells have not exceeded 5% under indoor illumination.
(32)

Among the various candidate materials available, hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells have high durability and band gaps of approximately 1.7 eV, which are ideal for matching the spectra of white LEDs.
(30)
In addition, Si is a nontoxic material that can easily be mass produced, a parameter that is of the utmost importance for sustainable and large-scale applications. When thin absorbing layers are employed to fabricate a-Si:H solar cells, separate patterns of metal grids—which can degrade visibility—are not required.
(36−40)
However, the PCEs of these cells under indoor light must also be improved to ensure tolerable transmittance because no such PV cells have yet shown a PCE higher than 20% under indoor lighting conditions.
(30,32)

Therefore, in this study, we report transparent a-Si:H solar cells with high-gap triple layers (HTMs) that showed a greatly increased shunt resistance, which is essential to achieving high PV performance under indoor illumination. The proposed transparent cell achieved a maximum PCE of 36.0% under indoor lighting conditions. Furthermore, color-adjusting multilayers (CAMs) were employed to meet the aesthetic needs of users.

Figure
2
shows the structure of the transparent solar cells suggested in this study. The cell structure was constructed as glass substrate/textured fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) (600 nm)/p-μc-Si:H (15 nm)/HTMs (a-Si:H; 27 nm)/i-a-Si:H (200 nm)/HTMs (a-Si:H; 27 nm)/n-μc-Si:H (20 nm)/GZO (700 nm)/CAMs [ultrathin silver 8 nm and gallium-doped zinc oxide (GZO); from 50 to 130 nm], as depicted in
Figure
2
. The HTMs, composed of 9 nm layers with
R
= 0.5, 2, and 6 (
R
= flow rate of H
2
/SiH
4
), were employed at the p/i and n/i interfaces. The increase in the value of
R
enhances the H incorporation of a-Si:H, resulting in an increase in the optical band gap. The effect of this HTM insertion is explained below. GZO films have been applied as transparent electrodes for transparent solar cells just like FTO films, instead of opaque metal electrodes. In conventional transparent solar cells that employ transparent electrodes on both sides without metal grids, the PCEs are lower than those of opaque solar cells because of decreased light absorption in the thinner light-absorbing layer (i.e., the i-layer) and high series resistance (
R
S
) under sunlight. Furthermore, in contrast with opaque cells containing highly reflective metal electrodes, transparent cells have less reflected light available to utilize. Therefore, the transparent solar cells proposed in this study were designed with special consideration given to parameters that are especially important for the indoor lighting environment.

div.p: Figure 2. Cell structure of proposed transparent solar cells.

div.div:
The equivalent circuit model, shown in
Figure S1
, was employed to extract the critical parameters affecting the PCE of a-Si:H solar cells under indoor lighting conditions. In the Shockley equation, illumination current density (
J
il
) and illumination voltage (
V
il
) can be solved analytically as a function of both shunt resistance (
R
P
) and
R
S
, as described in
eqs 1
–
3
.
(41)
(1)
(2)
(3)
Here,
J
0
is the reverse saturation current density,
J
SC
is the short-circuit current density under illumination,
V
il,indoor
is the voltage under indoor lighting,
T
is the temperature,
n
is the ideality factor,
q
is the elementary charge, and
k
is the Boltzmann constant (8.617 × 10
–5
eV K
–1
).
Equation 2
is an implicit function that can be obtained by modifying
eq 1
. Under indoor lighting, the intensity of which is very low,
R
S
disappears, and only
R
P
remains, when
J
il
approaches zero in
eq 3
. In this case,
V
il,indoor
approaches open-circuit voltage (
V
OC
), and hence
R
P
strongly affects
V
OC
. In general,
R
P
is commonly considered to be more crucial than
R
S
under dim light, including indoor light.
(11,16)
Therefore, to enhance the PCE under indoor lighting, the proposed structure was optimized based on
R
P
.

As shown in
Figure S2
, the optical band gaps of the i-layer and HTMs at the p/i and n/i interfaces were determined from transmittance measurements. Because
R
P
was considered the most crucial factor, HTMs composed of film layers with band gaps of 1.99 and 2.03 eV were employed at the p/i and n/i interfaces, respectively. These band gap energies were higher than the i-layer band gap of 1.81 eV. To elucidate the influence of the HTMs, a reference sample without HTMs (no-HTM) was fabricated and then compared with the cells including HTMs. Sample HTM-A contained the HTM only at the n/i interfaces, and sample HTM-B contained HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces.

The current density–voltage (J–V) characteristics were measured under cool white LED with 3000 lx illumination, and the results are shown in
Figure
3
a. Such LED lights are widely used in homes and offices and have replaced incandescent and fluorescent lamps because of their brightness and long life cycles.
(42)
Therefore, the conclusion that indoor PV cells should be developed to maximize efficiency under LED lights, rather than fluorescent or incandescent lamps, motivated the selection of white LEDs as the light source in this study. In
Figure
3
a and
Table
1
, sample HTM-A, with the HTM only at the n/i interface, shows a slightly lower
J
SC
compared to sample no-HTM, whereas sample HTM-B, with HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces, shows significant improvements in
J
SC
,
V
OC
, and fill factor (FF) under LED illumination. The PCEs of samples no-HTM and HTM-B were 24.9 and 34.0% under LED lights, respectively. As shown in
Figure S3a
, the external quantum efficiency (EQE) curves of all samples were measured, and the results indicated that sample HTM-B exhibited improved charge generation and collection over the entire wavelength range. In contrast, sample HTM-A showed decreased charge generation and collection over a short wavelength region, indicating that HTMs are more effective at improving the PCE when placed at the p/i interface.

div.p:
Figure 3. PV characteristics of proposed transparent solar cells. (a) Measured
J
–
V
curves of transparent solar cells with various HTM conditions under LED illumination, (b) schematic energy–band diagram for transparent solar cells with field-enhancing layers, (c) dark
J
–
V
curves of transparent solar cells with various HTM conditions, and (d) long-term stability of the fabricated a-Si:H solar cells (sample HTM-B) under continuous light illumination (3000 lx warm white LED).

div.div: Table 1. PV Parameters of Transparent Solar Cells with Various HTM Conditions under LED Illumination

div.p: Average and standard deviation values obtained from 12 devices are stated in parentheses.

div.div:
To ensure the effect of HTMs for enhancing
R
P
, a comparison of defect density between samples was carried out by analyzing biased EQE spectra and dark J–V curves. As the defect density is closely correlated with
R
P
, fewer defects result in
R
P
enhancements.
(43,44)
In addition to increasing
R
P
, collecting EQE spectra at reverse bias voltages made it possible to distinguish collection losses from optical losses. In p-i-n-type solar cells, the comparison of EQE (
Figure S3a
) at a given wavelength, with the corresponding EQE under reverse bias, enables differentiation between collection losses and optical losses, as shown in
Figure S3b
. Higher EQE
loss
[EQE(−2 V)/EQE(0 V)] indicates insufficient depletion resulting from defects or structural imperfection. Additionally, a more negative bias voltage induces a higher electric field in the i-layer, resulting in improved carrier collection.
(45)
As depicted in
Figure S3b
, sample HTM-B showed low EQE
loss
values over the entire wavelength range, implying that HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces can recover sufficiently from depletion. This analysis clearly shows that the introduction of HTMs increases
V
OC
and internal electric field intensity while decreasing the defect density, resulting in
R
P
enhancements. Based on these results, the effect of HTMs can be incorporated into the energy band diagram, as shown in
Figure
3
b, in which the energy band profiles were extracted from previous reports, and the measured band gap values were taken from the Tauc plots described above (
Figure S2
).
(46−48)
In sample HTM-A, an energy barrier formed at the n/i interface because of the presence of the high energy band gap, resulting in decreased charge collection. In contrast, in sample HTM-B, which provided surplus depletion charges through the HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces, the internal electric field effectively increased for both electrons and holes, as depicted in
Figure
3
b, resulting ultimately in increased
J
SC
,
V
OC
, and FF. From these results,
R
P
is shown to increase, based on the slope at
J
SC
in
Figure
3
a. Therefore, we could verify that the introduction of HTMs was very effective for enhancing
R
P
.

The other approach used to ensure the reduction of defect density was dark J–V behavior analysis. The PCE under indoor lighting is closely related to
J
0
as well as
R
P
, as described in
eq 3
. In this case, both
R
P
and
J
0
are associated with the defect density, and
J
0
is also responsible for degrading
V
OC
, particularly under extremely low light intensity. Therefore, a low
J
0
value tends to result in a high PCE in indoor environments. To demonstrate the effect of
J
0
, the dark J–V curves of the fabricated transparent solar cells and samples no-HTM, HTM-A, and HTM-B were measured and are shown in
Figure
3
c. As expected from
eq 3
, sample HTM-B showed a high
V
OC
of 0.755 V under LED illumination and had the lowest dark current density. The increase in charge collection because of the HTMs at both sides also increased
J
SC
, resulting in a high
J
SC
of 625.1 μA cm
–2
and a high PCE of 34.0%. Furthermore, the long-term stability of solar cells is essential for commercial applications. It has been reported that a major disadvantage of amorphous silicon is the light-induced degradation that occurs during illumination of cells. The so-called Staebler–Wronski Effect reduces the efficiency by breaking weak silicon–hydrogen bonds in the i-layer, thus leading to an increase in the density of defects.
(49)
This effect depends heavily on the quality of the intrinsic a-Si layer, the thickness of the layer, the operation temperature, and certain other miscellaneous parameters. The emission spectrum of the LED is different from that of sunlight and does not include the wavelength band of the ultraviolet region, which is a major cause of breaking silicon–hydrogen bonds. This indicates the possibility that amorphous silicon can operate much more stably in an indoor environment unlike an outdoor environment. Even if the defect density is increased slightly, we expect that the internal electric field is improved because of the HTM proposed in this study; therefore, the reduction rate of the efficiency under LED illumination is extremely low. To investigate PCE degradation under indoor environments, the fabricated a-Si:H solar cell (sample HTM-B) was tested under 3000 lx LED illumination for 200 h under open circuit conditions. Impressively, as shown in
Figure
3
d, the cell sustained over 99% of original PCE after illuminating it for 200 h, thereby suggesting that a-Si:H solar cells have the highest stability when compared to OPV and perovskite solar cells.
(29)

One strategy to improve PCE under indoor lighting is to vary the thickness of the light-absorbing layer because photocurrent is expected to increase with absorbing layer thickness. Although the internal field for charge collection typically decreases with a thicker i-layer under sunlight, this effect may be reduced under dimmer light conditions. In these conditions, the thicker layer may be advantageous because the enhanced charge generation could result in an increased
J
SC
.

Figure
4
shows the illuminated J–V characteristics with varying i-layer thicknesses from 100 to 300 nm, maintaining the cell structure with HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces (HTM-B) under AM1.5G and LED illumination, and the corresponding performance parameters are listed in
Table
2
. A substantial improvement in
J
SC
values was achieved with increasing i-layer thicknesses under both AM1.5G and LED illumination, and the EQE results are shown in
Figure S4a
. Contrary to cells under AM1.5G illumination, significant decreases were not observed in either the
V
OC
or FF values with increased i-layer thickness in cells under indoor lighting. This is because of the reduced dependency of
V
OC
on
J
il
, as can be seen by comparing
eqs 2
and
3
.
Figure S4b
shows the PCEs as a function of thickness under white LED illumination with intensity varied from 500 to 6000 lux. The i-300 case, denoting the 300 nm-thick i-layer, showed the best performance overall, with a superb PCE of 36.0% under 3000 lx illumination with an irradiation of 0.92 mW cm
–2
. To the best of our knowledge, this is the best PCE value ever reported for transparent solar cells. Although it is difficult to implement 3000 lx illuminance environment indoors, like in a house or dormitory, we expect that such a high illuminance will be required in special environments such as a department store show window.

div.p: Figure 4. PV characteristics of transparent solar cells. Measured J–V curves of transparent solar cells with various intrinsic thicknesses under (a) AM1.5G and (b) LED illumination.

div.div: Table 2. PV Parameters of Transparent Solar Cells with Various Intrinsic Thicknesses under AM1.5G (1 Sun) and LED Illumination

div.p: Average and standard deviation values obtained from 12 devices are stated in parentheses.

div.div:
To ensure the transparency of the solar cells, their transmittance in the wavelength range of 500–800 nm was measured, and the results are shown in
Figure
5
. In transparent solar cells, the transparency and PCE can each only be enhanced at the expense of the other, as has been previously reported, that is, cells with high transparency suffer from low PCE, and vice versa. However, in this study, the average transmittance was almost invariant between the samples with varied HTMs while the PCE was improved under both AM1.5G and LED illumination, upon employing HTMs. To evaluate both the PCE and transparency of the fabricated solar cells, we defined the figure of merit (FOM) as the product of these two parameters, and the results are listed in
Table S1
.
(40)
Although sample i-300 showed the highest PCE of 36.0%, its FOM was lower than that of the HTM-B sample with an i-layer thickness of 200 nm (sample i-200), as transparency was dependent on the i-layer thickness. Sample i-200 was, therefore, considered the most desirable for applications requiring both high PCE and transparency, with an FOM of 833.3.

div.p: Figure 5. Optical properties of transparent solar cells. (a) Transmittance of cells with various HTM conditions, and (b) transmittance of cells with various intrinsic thicknesses.

div.div:
As shown in
Figure
1
b, transparent solar cells can be used for value-added applications such as windows, transparent displays, and other transparent electronic devices. For widespread uptake in various applications, both outdoors and indoors, aesthetic diversity aids marketability, and color adjustment technology are, therefore, important aesthetic element in various markets. In this study, we succeeded in implementing various colors by employing CAMs on the top electrodes and using optical interference, varying the optical thickness as detailed in the
Experimental Section
.
Figure
6
a,b shows the colored transparent solar cells, in red, orange, pink, and yellow-green, obtained by controlling the optical thickness of the CAMs in each solar cell.
Figure
6
c shows the illuminated J–V curves under white LED illumination, in which the
J
SC
is slightly reduced because of optical losses, and
V
OC
values are almost constant. The resulting PCEs varied within 10% under white LED lighting, as detailed in
Table S2
. The average transmittance of the different colors varied slightly, as presented in
Table S3
, and further study is recommended to identify a technical solution to reduce this variation.

div.p:
Figure 6. PV and optical properties with various CAM conditions. (a) Photographs of transparent a-Si:H solar cells, (b) photographs of colored a-Si:H solar cells, (c) measured
J
–
V
curves, and (d) transmittance of the cells with various CAM conditions.

div.div:
In recent years, competition has intensified in the quest to achieve the highest PCE under dim light conditions. Additionally, in a small cell, the PCE is likely to be exaggerated because the measurement process does not include the shadowing that occurs in practical conditions. Also, in the case of indoor PVs, the number of excess carriers generated is extremely small; hence, even a minute current value greatly affects PCE. Therefore, in this study, we worked to obtain more accurate PCE values using a shadow mask in the J–V measurements, and we compared the PCE values both with and without the mask.
Figure S5a,b
shows transparent solar cells fabricated on a 5 cm × 5 cm glass substrate with and without the mask, respectively. As presented in
Table S4
, the cell without the shadow mask showed an increased
J
SC
, resulting in a very high PCE of 44.2%, which was considered an exaggerated value, and indicated that the mask was an essential component in a measurement process that would obtain accurate values. The measured EQEs of all the solar cells investigated in this study were verified by matching with the measured
J
SC
values, which indicated that the PCEs were not exaggerated.

Table
3
compares the results of previous studies and those of this work under indoor lighting conditions. Although the OPV and perovskite solar cells reported in ref
(7)
showed high PCEs under LED illumination, the input power of the incident light was too high to be relevant for indoor applications. Recently, perovskite solar cells reported in ref
(29)
showed recorded high PCEs under fluorescent lamps. Nevertheless, the device stability needs to be improved, and the cells are only suitable for opaque devices, resulting in limitations for use in various electronic applications. In this study, transparent a-Si:H thin-film solar cells achieved the record-breaking PCE of 36.0%, which is comparable to the highest PCE of 36.2% produced by opaque solar cells. Furthermore, these materials are more promising than organic-based solar cells in that they provide the durability and stability necessary for commercialization.
Table 3. Performance Comparison of Proposed and Previously Reported Solar Cells under Indoor Illumination

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In conclusion, we employed HTMs at both the n/i and p/i interfaces of transparent and colored a-Si:H solar cells to enhance VOC and FF, and subsequently, the PCE. In particular, the HTMs were very effective at improving the PCE under indoor lighting. In addition, by increasing the i-layer thickness to 300 nm, a PCE of 36.0% was achieved with a reasonable transmittance of 20.44% under white LED illumination, with an intensity of 3000 lux. The best performance of the proposed cell, when considering both transmittance and PCE, was achieved with the HTM-B cell with a 200-nm-thick i-layer, having a PCE of 34.0% and a transmittance of 24.5%. The fabricated transparent solar cells exhibit excellent long-term stability with negligible PCE degradation under continuous indoor light for 200 h. In addition, aesthetically attractive a-Si:H solar cells colored red, orange, pink, and yellow-green were achieved using optical interference, and these offer greater diversity for electronic applications such as transparent displays and smart windows. These colored transparent a-Si:H solar cells could, therefore, contribute to the rapid expansion of applications such as indoor wireless sensors, transparent displays, windows, and future IoT applications.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
FTO (SnO
2
:F) glass with a sheet resistance of 10 Ω sq
–1
was used as the substrate for the solar cells. The substrates were each cleaned three times in sequential ultrasonic baths of acetone, deionized water, and isopropanol and then dried with pressurized nitrogen flow. Transparent and opaque a-Si:H solar cells were fabricated on clean FTO glasses using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition at 13.56 MHz. The p-i-n layers and HTMs were deposited in a single chamber at 200 °C, using SiH
4
, PH
3
(1.5% diluted in H
2
), B
2
H
6
(0.1% diluted in H
2
), and H
2
gases. The GZO layers were deposited by radio-frequency magnetron sputtering at room temperature. A ZnO ceramic target with a diameter of 4 in, with a 99.99% purity and 5 wt % Ga
2
O
3
, was employed as the sputtering target. For optical band gap engineering of HTMs, we varied the hydrogen dilution ratio (
R
), defined as the ratio of the flow rates of hydrogen and silane gases (H
2
/SiH
4
), during plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition. A film with a lower
R
will exhibit a wider optical band gap energy.

Using an optical microscope, the active area for each individual cell was estimated to be approximately 0.25 cm
2
. In addition, CAMs composed of ultrathin metal (Ag) with 8 nm thickness and thin oxide layers (GZO) with varying thicknesses (50–130 nm) were deposited by sputtering, with total thicknesses controlled within the range of 60 to 130 nm.

For the optical and electrical measurements of the solar cells, matte black measuring plates were used to avoid any possible overestimation of efficiency because of reflection. Current density–voltage (J–V) characteristics under AM 1.5 Global (G) illumination were measured using a source meter (2401, Keithley Instruments, Cleveland, OH, USA) controlled by a simulation program. When testing the solar cells under solar irradiation, an AM1.5G solar simulator with an irradiance of 100 mW cm
–2
was used as the light source. To estimate the performance of solar cells under indoor lighting conditions, LED lamps (OSRAM, Munich, Germany) with color temperatures of 3000 and 6500 K were employed.
Figure
1
c shows the emission spectra of the LED sources compared with the AM1.5G spectrum. The irradiations of the 3000-K LED lamps were 0.31 and 0.92 mW cm
–2
at 1000 and 3000 lux, respectively. The emission spectra, irradiation, and illuminance values were measured using a spectroradiometer (PS-300, Apogee Instruments, USA). The advantage with this equipment is that radiance and illumination can be measured simultaneously with no changes in position, depending on the distance from the object receiving the light. In addition, radiance and illumination at the edge of the LED bulb were measured. Detector performance of the spectroradiometer is also better than typical luxmeters and portable luxmeters. The PV test under LED illumination is explained in detail in the Supporting Information document. The EQE of the a-Si:H solar cells was measured with an incident-photon-to-current efficiency measurement system. The optical transmittance was measured using an ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometer, and the sheet resistance of the transparent electrodes was measured using a four-point probe technique.

Low light illumination study on commercially available homojunction photovoltaic cells
Russo, Johnny; Ray, William, II; Litz, Marc S.

Low illumination (10-4 suns) and indoor light energy harvesting is needed to meet the demands of zero net energy (ZNE) building, Internet of Things (IoT), and beta-photovoltaic energy harvesting systems to power remote sensors. Photovoltaic (PV) solar cells under low intensity and narrow (±40 nm) light spectrum conditions are not well characterized nor developed, esp. for com. available devices and scalable systems. PV operating characteristics under 1 sun illumination decrease at lower light intensity and narrow spectrum conditions (efficiency drops from ∼25% at 100 mWopt/cm2 to 2% at 1μWopt/cm2). By choosing a PV with a bandgap that matches the light source operating wavelength, the total system efficiency can be improved. By quantifying losses on homojunction photovoltaics (thermalization and leakage current), we have detd. the theor. optimized efficiency for a set of PV material and a selected set of light sources. We measure single-junction solar cells' parameters under three different light sources (indoor light and narrow spectrum LED sources) with light intensities ranging from 0.5 to 100μWopt/cm2. Measurements show that indium gallium phosphide (InGaP) PV has the highest surface power d. and conversion efficiency (29% under ≈1μWopt/cm2 from a 523 nm central peak LED). A beta-photovoltaic exptl. study identifies InGaP to be optimized for use with the ZnS:Cu, Al and tritium at STP. The results have guided the selection of PV material for scalable isotope batteries and other low-light energy harvesting systems.

The field of org. photovoltaics (OPVs) has long focused on matching silicon solar cells, both in high power conversion efficiency (PCE) under solar light and broad absorption of the solar spectrum. We show that OPV devices, which have significantly lower PCEs than high-performing cryst. silicon cells when measured under the typical AM 1.5G solar std., can surpass silicon cells with PCEs >20% measured under LED light. We highlight that the conflation of the terms "solar cell" and "photovoltaic" gives an incomplete view of the potential of many photovoltaic materials, esp. org. materials. By expanding the definition and assessment of photovoltaic devices to include multiple light sources, OPVs-with their higher PCEs under indoor light and qual. benefits of being lightwt., thin, flexible, and semi-transparent-could have a home in previously unconsidered low-power indoor applications.

Solar cell comparison is generally based on an arbitrary max. terrestrial intensity and spectra (of 1 sun, 1000 W/m2) at 25° perpendicular to the cell plane referred to by specialists as AM1.5. In practice, no solar cell experiences such conditions, yet few alternative bases for comparison exist. The interest in this paper is to explore the correct design of indoor Photovoltaic (IPV) products. Given that the indoors, when compared with the outdoors, are characterized by much lower radiant energy intensities, various spectra (including artificial light sources), more general level reports were published, but complete comparison data for indoor conditions are not freely available. Twenty-one different solar cells representing eight different Photovoltaic material technologies are reproducibly elec. characterized under lab. based simulated AM1.5 (1 sun; solar spectrum) from 1000 W/m2 intensity down to the 0.1-1 W/m2 decade. Some were measured under an artificial light source (fluorescent tube) in the 1-10 W/m2 decade. The results are used to validate a phenomenol. based model.

Recently, while increasing research has been focused toward improving the efficiency of various photovoltaic devices under low light intensities, few studies have reported on multi-donor-, multi-acceptor-based bulk heterojunctions (BHJ). In this study, we have demonstrated the utilization of a quaternary BHJ for indoor light energy harvesting applications. We utilized a PCDTBT:PTB7:PC61BM:PC71BM-based BHJ structure in order to improve the morphol., absorption window, and the charge transport properties of the photovoltaic device. The ability of ternary photovoltaics to attain high power-conversion efficiency (PCE) by improving the morphol. and the charge transport properties had already been validated in another study. We show that the advantages of a stable quaternary solar cell can also be achieved with an optimized BHJ compn. ratio of 5:5:3:12, which provides a PCE of 10.6%. Our device showed high shunt resistance and low series resistance, thus facilitating appreciable charge extn. even under low-intensity light conditions such as 500 lx white LED illumination.

An in-depth study on the photovoltaic characteristics under indoor lights, i.e., light-emitting diode (LED), fluorescent lamps, and halogen lamps, was performed with varying the photoactive layer thickness (120-870 nm), by comparing those under 1-sun condition. The semi-cryst. mid-gap photoactive polymer, poly[(2,5-bis(2-hexyldecyloxy)phenylene)-alt-(5,6-difluoro-4,7-di(thiophen-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PPDT2FBT) and a fullerene deriv., [6,6]-Ph C71 butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) were used as a photoactive layer. In the contrary to the measurements under 1-sun condition, the indoor devices show a clearly different behavior, showing the thickness tolerant short-circuit c.d. (JSC) and fill factor (FF) values with 280-870 nm thick photoactive layers. The retained JSC and FF values of thick indoor devices were discussed in terms of the parasitic resistance effects based on the single-diode equiv. circuit model. The much lower series/shunt resistance (Rs/RP) ratio was measured with thick photoactive layer (≥280 nm), resulting in negligible decreases in the JSC and FF values even with a 870-nm-thick active layer under the LED condition. Under 1000 lx LED light, the PPDT2FBT:PC70BM device showed an optimum power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 16% (max power d., 44.8μW/cm2) with an open-circuit voltage of 587 mV, a JSC of 117μA/cm2, and a FF of 65.2. The device with a 870-nm-thick active layer still exhibited an excellent performance with a PCE of 12.5%. These results clearly suggest that the crit. parasitic resistance effects on the performance vary depending on the light illumination condition, and the large RP assocd. with the viable thick photoactive layer and the well-matched absorption (of photoactive layer) with the irradiance spectrum (of indoor light) are essential to realize efficient indoor photovoltaic cells with high JSC and FF.

The objective of this study is to det. the photovoltaic properties of inverted org. photovoltaic devices (OPVs) that employ indium-tin oxide (ITO) modified by ethoxylated polyethylenimine (PEIE) as an electron-collecting electrode under indoor lighting conditions. Owing to the reduced current generation at low light intensity, possessing a sufficiently large shunt resistance (RP) assocd. with a low leakage current is of utmost importance for performance maximization. The photovoltaic properties under this lighting condition were optimized by controlling the thickness of the PEIE layers, and the elec., optical, and surface properties of the PEIE-modified ITO were detd. Inverted OPVs based on poly(3-hexylthiophene)-indene-C60 bisadduct (P3HT-ICBA) with an 8.5-nm-thick PEIE layer yielded a max. power-conversion efficiency (PCE) of 13.9% under an LED light with a luminance of 500 lx. Meanwhile, the same device showed poor performance with a PCE of 3.1% under 1 sun illumination owing to the insulating nature of PEIE.

A porphyrin-based donor material P1 is used to fabricate bulk-heterojunction solar cells harvesting room light. P1 consists of a porphyrin ring linked by two ethylrhodanine end caps via phenylene ethynylene bridges. Org. photovoltaic (OPV) cells using P1 as the donor exhibit significantly improved performances under indoor illumination compared to 1 sun conditions. For P1:PC71BM cells, an optimized-PCE of 19.2% was achieved under a 300 lx illumination of a 3000 K LED tube. Besides high PCEs, the porphyrin-based devices also exhibit enhanced OPV performances in thick film regions (∼200 nm) compared to a control BHJ cell using PCDTBT:PC71BM. The thick-film P1-based device shows an overall PCE of 18.2%. The origins of the thickness independent OPV performances were examd., and they can be attributed to the low electronic disorders of these materials when compared to their polymer counterparts.

We synthesized 3 semicryst. polymers (PTTBTBO, PDTBTBO, and P2FDTBTBO) by modulating the intra- and intermol. noncovalent Coulombic interactions and investigated their photovoltaic characteristics under various light intensities. Low series (Rs) and high shunt (Rsh) resistances are essential prerequisites for good device properties under std. illumination (100 mW/cm2). Considering these factors, among 3 polymers, PDTBTBO polymer solar cells (PSCs) exhibited the most desirable characteristics, with peak power conversion efficiencies (PCE) of 7.52 and 9.60% by being blended with PC71BM under std. and dim light (2.5 mW/cm2), resp. P2FDTBTBO PSCs exhibited a low PCE of 3.69% under std. light due to significant charge recombination with high Rs (9.42 Ωcm2). However, the PCE was remarkably improved by 2.3 times (8.33% PCE) under dim light, showing negligible decrease in open-circuit voltage and remarkable increase in fill factor, which is due to an exceptionally high Rsh of over 1000 KΩcm2. Rs is less significant under dim light because the generated current is too small to cause noticeable Rs-induced voltage losses. Instead, high Rsh becomes more important to avoid leakage currents. This work provides important tips to further optimize PSCs for indoor applications with low-power electronic devices such as Internet of things sensors.

Photovoltaic cells are attracting significant interest for harvesting indoor light for low power consumption wireless electronics such as those required for smart homes and offices, and the rapidly-growing Internet of Things. Here, we explore the potential of soln. processable, small mol. photovoltaic cells as indoor power sources. By optimizing the solvent vapor annealing (SVA) time for the photovoltaic layer, a balance between its crystn. and phase sepn. is obtained, resulting in a record power conversion efficiency (PCE) of over 28% under fluorescent lamps of 1000 lx, generating a max. power d. of 78.2 μW cm-2 (>10% PCE under AM1.5G). This high indoor performance surpasses that of silicon based photovoltaic cells, and is similar to that of gallium arsenide photovoltaic cells. Besides, the ratios of the voltage at the max. power point (MPP) to the open circuit voltage are similar from indoor lighting to one sun conditions, which is unique and allows a less power consuming method to track the MPP for a broad range of light intensities (potentially attractive for wearable photovoltaics). New insight into the effect of SVA on the indoor and one sun performance is provided using advanced optoelectronic characterization techniques, which show that the mobility-lifetime products as a function of charge carrier d. can be correlated well with the performance at different light levels. Our results suggest that org. photovoltaic cells could be promising as indoor power sources for self-sustainable electronics.

We used several polymers as the ternary components to demonstrate a ternary strategy to improve the performance of PCDTBT:PC71BM devices under 1 sun and indoor illumination. With a binary bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) of PCDTBT:PC71BM org. photovoltaic (OPV) cell, a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 16.5% under indoor light sources (300 lx from fluorescence tube) was achieved. However, with a ternary BHJ cell of PCDTBT:PDTSTPD:PC71BM, the PCE can be enhanced to 20.8%. FFs are the primarily improved in these devices. Transport and absorption measurements indicate the origins of the improvements of OPV performance: the ternary BHJ films exhibit enhanced hole mobilities and reduced Urbach energies, indicating that the blending of the PDTSTPD component passivates shallow traps near the band edges of the BHJ films.

Wireless sensor network becomes widespread into home and offices to keep them comfort and save the energy. The battery-less wireless sensor nodes need the high performance indoor solar cells for stable and sustainable operation. Org. Photovoltaics (OPV) has great indoor photovoltaic performance because ultra-thin org. layer has strong absorption against the UV-visible spectrum that is good spectral matching with indoor lightings. In this study, OPV module has 8 cells in series and same size as the conventional amorphous silicon solar cells (a-Si) for indoor light harvesting. OPV and a-Si are measured their photovoltaic performance under the fluorescent light and demonstrated for energy harvester of wireless sensor network. The output power of OPV and a-Si is 43.4 μW cm-2 and 28.5 μW cm-2 at fluorescent light 1000lx resp. The data transmission rate of the wireless sensor node driven by OPV is 30-40% improved under the dim light condition compared to a-Si.

Since their introduction, dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) have achieved huge success at a lab. level. Recently, research is concd. to visualize large DSC modules at the com. platform. We tested structurally simple porphyrin-based dye SK6 and anthracene-based dye CW10 for DSCs application under simulated 1 sun (AM 1.5G) and indoor light sources. These 2 dyes can be easily synthesized and yet are efficient with cell performances of ∼5.42 and ∼5.75% (without coadsorbent/additive) for SK6 and CW10, resp., under AM 1.5G illumination. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of SK6 reported here is the highest ever reported; this is achieved by optimizing the adsorption of SK6 on TiO2 photoanode using the most suitable solvent and immersion period. Cosensitization of SK6 with CW10 on TiO2 surface has boosted cell performance further and achieved PCE of ∼6.31% under AM 1.5G illumination. Charge-transfer properties of individual and cosensitized devices at TiO2/dye/electrolyte interface were examd. via electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. To understand the cell performances under ambient light conditions, we soaked individual and cosensitized devices under T5 and light-emitting diode light sources of 300-6000 lx. The PCE of ∼22.91% under T5 light (6000 lx) with JSC =0.883 mA/cm2, VOC =0.646 V, and FF =0.749 was noted for the cosensitized device, which equals a power output of 426 μW/cm2. These results reveal that DSCs made of structurally simple dyes performed efficiently under both 1 sun (AM 1.5G) and indoor light conditions, which is undoubtedly a significant achievement when it comes to a choice of com. application.

Titanium (Ti) has high potential in many practical applications such as biomedicine, architecture, aviation, and energy. In this study, we demonstrate an innovative application of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) based on Ti photoanodes that can be integrated into the roof engineering of large-scale architectures. A chromatic Ti foil produced by anodizing oxidn. (coloring) technol. is an attractive roof material for large-scale architecture, showing a colorful appearance due to the formation of a reflective TiO2 thin layer on both surfaces of Ti. The DSSC is fabricated on the backside of the chromatic Ti foil using the Ti foil as the working electrode, and this roof-DSSC hybrid configuration can be designed as an energy harvesting device for indoor artificial lighting. Our results show that the facet-textured TiO2 layer on the chromatic Ti foil not only improves the optical reflectance for better light utilization but also effectively suppresses the charge recombination for better electron collection. The power conversion efficiency of the roof-DSSC hybrid system is improved by 30-40% with a main contribution from an improvement of short-circuit c.d. under std. 1 sun and dim-light (600-1000 lx) illumination.

Power generation in indoor environments is the next step in dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) evolution. To achieve this goal, a crit. recombination route which is usually inhibited by the TiCl4-derived blocking layers (BLs), i.e., charge transfer at the fluorine-doped tin oxide substrate/electrolyte interface, is of concern. In this study, we demonstrate that because of low surface coverage, the conventional TiCl4 BLs are unable to suppress such electron leakage, thus limiting the photovoltaic performance of Co(bpy)32+/3+-mediated DSSCs (bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine) under ambient lighting. On the other hand, by introducing compact BLs prepd. by spray pyrolysis, the DSSCs show lower dark current and operate efficiently not only under high-intensity sunlight but also under ambient light conditions. The better blocking function of the compact BL is verified by the cyclic voltammetry; other thin-film prepn. methods, except for the common TiCl4 treatment, are anticipated to realize a similar blocking effect. This study illustrates that dense thin film with a predominant blocking function is highly required as the BL for DSSCs under low-light conditions, and this concept will pave the way for more development of indoor DSSCs.

We present new architectures in CH3NH3PbI3 based planar perovskite solar cells incorporating soln. processed SnO2/MgO composite electron transport layers that show the highest power outputs ever reported for photovoltaic cells under typical 200-400 1x indoor illumination conditions. When measured under white OSRAM LED lamp (200, 400 1x), the max. power d. values were 20.2 μW/cm2 (estd. power conversion efficiency, PCE = 25.0%) at 200 1x and 41.6 μW/cm2 (PCE = 26.9%) at 400 1x which correspond to a ∼ 20% increment compared to solar cells with a SnO2 layer only (even at std. 1 sun illumination, where the max. PCE was 19.0%). The thin MgO overlayer leads to more uniform films, reduces interfacial carrier recombination, and leads to better stability. All layers of the cells, except for the two electrodes, are soln. processed at low temps. for low cost processing. Furthermore, ambient indoor conditions represent a milder environment compared to stringent outdoor conditions for a technol. that is still looking for a com. outlet also due to stability concerns. The unparalleled performance here demonstrated, paves the way for perovskite solar cells to contribute strongly to the powering of the indoor electronics of the future (e.g. smart autonomous indoor wireless sensor networks, internet of things etc).

Indoor photovoltaics are promising to enable self-powered electronic devices for the Internet of Things. Here, reported is a triple-anion CH3NH3PbI2-xBrClx perovskite film, of which the bandgap is specially designed for indoor light harvesting to achieve a record high efficiency of 36.2% with distinctive high open circuit voltage (Voc) of 1.028 V under std. 1000 lx fluorescent light. The involvement of both bromide and chloride suppresses the trap-states and nonradiative recombination loss, exhibiting a remarkable ideality factor of 1.097. The introduction of chloride successfully restrains the halide segregation of iodide and bromide, stabilizing the triple-anion perovskite film. The devices show an excellent long-term performance, sustaining over 95% of original efficiency under continuous light soaking over 2000 h. These findings show the importance and potential of I/Br/Cl triple-anion perovskite with tailored bandgap and suppressed trap-states in stable and efficient indoor light recycling.

Effects of drying and wetting cycles on the transformations of extraneous inorganic N to soil microbial residues
Zhang, Wei; Liang, Chao; Kao-Kniffin, Jenny; He, Hongbo; Xie, Hongtu; Zhang, Xudong
Scientific Reports
(

The incorporation of extraneous nitrogen (N) into amino sugars (AS) could reflect the contribution of microbial residues to soil N transformation. Investigating the impact of drying-wetting (DW) on dynamics of newly-produced AS is crit. because this represents microbial-driven N retention/losses in soil. A 36-day incubation of soil samples was conducted under different drying intensities, using 15N-labeled-(NH4)2SO4 as an N source together with/without glucose addn. There were multiple DW periods and they ranged from a const. moisture content treatment, to a one day drying (low-drying-intensity, LD), a two day drying (medium-drying-intensity, MD), or a three day drying event (severe-drying-intensity, SD). The immobilization of added-N was restricted in DW when available carbon was not added, thus glucose addn. increased the effect of DW on the incorporation of added-N into AS. The response of total 15N-AS to DW varied depending on drying intensities. The MD was beneficial to the incorporation of added-N into total 15N-AS, while total 15N-AS contents were low in SD treatment. The effect of DW on contribution of bacterial and fungal residues to N transformation was also related to drying intensities. Our study indicated that DW altered microbial transformation of added-N, and the effect was drying intensity-specific, and available carbon-dependent.

Illumination intensity and spectrum-dependent performance of thin-film silicon single and multijunction solar cells
Agbo, S. N.; Merdzhanova, T.; Rau, U.; Astakhov, O.
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells
(
2017
),

(

The performance of a solar cell is inherently dependent on the illumination spectrum and intensity. Therefore std. characterization under AM1.5 illumination represents only one point in a large parameter space. In view of potential applications in portable electronics, obtaining ref. data on the performance under varying light sources and illumination intensity for a comprehensive set of thin-film silicon solar cells (TFSC) is a primary motivation of our study. In addn., illumination dependencies of photovoltaic parameters provide deeper understanding of the operation and limitations of thin-film silicon solar cell for both indoor and outdoor applications. In this paper we assess the performance of single and multijunction TFSC with amorphous (a-Si:H) and microcryst. (μc-Si:H) absorber layers under common light sources like light emitting diode (LED), halogen, fluorescent and solar simulator with AM1.5 spectrum. The illumination intensity of these light sources has been varied over several orders of magnitude (0.01-230 mW/cm2) to explore a wide range of operating conditions for the solar cells. We obsd. expected increase in efficiency with increase of the illumination intensity (up to approx. 1 sun) of all cells and naturally strong dependence on the illumination spectrum. For example, the efficiency reached impressive 20% for a-Si:H cells under LED illumination while it is below 4% under halogen bulb. More detailed anal. performed in this work shows that the cell parameters are not always following diode model predictions mostly due to the bias-dependent collection in drift driven thin-film silicon solar cells. The results first of all provide ref. for the assessment of energy gain from TFSC in various illumination conditions. It also provides better view into the limitations of TFSC and potentials for improvement esp. for the non-std. illumination spectra and intensities.

We report on soln.-processed, semitransparent org. solar cells that are implemented as lenses in sunglasses. The elec. power provided by the lens-fitted solar cells sustains a microelectronic circuit that is used to read out temp. and illumination intensity sensors and to make this information available on two displays integrated into the temples of the "Solar Glasses". The microelectronic circuit is designed to operate at illumination intensities down to 500 lx, rendering the Solar Glasses suitable for outdoor and indoor use as well as for operation in diffuse light. Hence, this case study provides an example for consumer-oriented mobile applications, self-powered by integrated solar cells, which specifically exploit the unique properties of org. solar cells.

We have studied the solar cell behavior under variable light intensity (VLI) of a std. a-Si:H pin solar cell with a wide band gap a-SiC:H emitter layer, and micro-cryst. (μc)-Si:H solar cells of different degrees of crystallinity, using expts. in conjunction with detailed elec.-optical modeling. Both expts. and modeling reveal that whereas the fill factor (FF) of the a-Si:H pin cell decreases with increasing light intensity, starting from a low applied light bias, that of the μc-Si:H cells increases with light intensity over a major part of this range. This fact enables one to attain the max. of the open-circuit voltage - fill factor product (Voc × FF) at 1 to 2 suns intensity for the latter case; however this is not achieved for the a-Si:H cell. Using modeling we try to understand this difference in behavior of the FF under VLI for the two types of cells. We also predict under what conditions it would be possible to shift the (Voc × FF)max for the a-Si:H cell towards one sun intensity.

Kim, Gayoung; Lim, Jung Wook; Shin, Myunghun; Yun, Sun Jin

Transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin-film solar cells, in which the colors of the front and rear faces can be adjusted individually, were developed for implementation in building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. The proposed ultrathin transparent multilayered electrodes (TMEs) are highly conductive and transparent, consisting of a bottom layer of gallium-doped zinc oxide (GZO), a thin metal layer of Ag, and an optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL) of GZO. They can be used for both the front and rear electrodes of transparent a-Si:H solar cells, and the resulting solar cells show a 5.0% av. power conversion efficiency and 18.3% av. transmittance. The various dual colors on the front and rear of the cell can be individually adjusted by changing the thickness of the OCL on each face of the TME, without significantly changing the efficiency. The cell colors were quant. investigated using the color coordinates in a chromaticity diagram based on the International Commission on Illumination (CIE; 1931) std. to show that the simulated and obsd. colors match well under both LED and fluorescent light sources. We also show that the observable color of the BIPV windows is detd. by indoor and outdoor light sources, and dynamically varies as a function of illuminance of the light source as the day gradually progresses into night. This study helps to elucidate the color behavior of the BIPV windows and to develop a-Si:H BIPV windows that show various colors with stable elec. power generation.

A low temp. deposition process was developed to fabricate ultra-thin, transparent, multi-layered electrodes (TMEs) suitable to be used on variously shaped flexible substrates, as those utilized in the transparent solar cells of building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) systems. The fabricated TMEs consisted of a bottom layer (BL) of gallium doped zinc oxide (GZO), an Ag-layer, and optoelectronic-controlling layers (OCLs) of GZO; and exhibited a high transmittance of 90% at 550 nm, and a low sheet resistance of 9.4 Ω/sq. at the thickness of ∼ 100 nm. Because the Ag of TMEs easily detach from inorg. or amorphous surfaces, the GZO-BL was chem. treated in a dild. acetic and nitric acid mixt. (10:2) to generate changes in its surface energy and improve the Ag adhesion. To quant. evaluate the Ag adhesion of TMEs, we proposed and conducted a tape pull-out adhesion test, and found the optimum GZO-BL texturing condition. The developed TMEs were used as the front transparent conductive electrodes of transparent a-Si:H solar cells to tune their reflection colors. By changing the thickness of the OCL, a wide range of colors was obtained without serious efficiency variations, as was predicted by optical simulations. The fabricated transparent cells show a high efficiency of 4.8%, as well as a high av. transmittance of ∼ 20% in the visible range. The developed TME structure, using the proposed deposition process, can be fabricated on various substrates and can be applied to devices that require a variety of colors such as BIPVs, wearable PVs, and the PVs of moving vehicles.

We fabricated hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si: H) transparent solar cells using ultrathin transparent multi-layered electrodes (TMEs) as rear-side transparent electrodes for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. Each TME included a bottom layer, thin Ag layer, and optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL). The TMEs were exptl. designed to have high transparency and conductance. The fabricated a-Si:H transparent solar cells showed optimal performance with a 6.36% power-conversion efficiency and 23.5% av. transmittance (500-800 nm) when TMEs with a thickness less than 160 nm were incorporated. We demonstrated that the reflection color of the cell could be tuned without serious loss of cell efficiency by varying the thickness of the OCL. The backside colors were predicted to be the coordinates on a CIE 1931 chromaticity diagram using the reflection spectrum from the cell and emission spectrum of a 50 W LED light source. The developed a-Si:H transparent solar cells exhibited high efficiency and show feasibility for incorporating various colors in the photovoltaic and aesthetic functionalities of BIPV windows.

We showed that thin n-type CuOx films can be deposited by radio-frequency magnetron reactive sputtering and demonstrated the fabrication of n-CuOx/intrinsic hydrogenated amorphous silicon (i-a-Si:H) heterojunction solar cells (HSCs) for the first time. A highly n-doped hydrogenated microcryst. Si (n-μc-Si:H) layer was introduced as a depletion-assisting layer to further improve the performance of n-CuOx/i-a-Si:H HSCs. We used very thin (i.e., ∼115-nm-thick) absorbers to fabricate full-penetration (FP) semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows and introduced high-bandgap (HB) n/i-interface layers to decrease shunt loss and increase carrier collection. The optoelectronic properties of the fabricated cells showed that the HB layers improved the fill factor by decreasing shunt loss and increased the short-circuit c.d. by enhancing generated-carrier collection. We used scattering matrix anal. to simulate the transmittance characteristics of the semitransparent solar cells fabricated using the HB layers and showed that the HB layers shifted the transmission peak to longer wavelengths. We used a figure of merit (FOM), the product of the efficiency and the av. transmittance in the range 400-800 nm, to represent the performance of the semitransparent solar cells and compared the FOMs of the cells fabricated for application to BIPV windows. The cell fabricated using triple HB layers showed the highest FOM, more than 20% higher efficiency than the ref. cell (fabricated without using any HB layers), and its transmittance was similar to that of the ref. cell. Fabricating FP semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells with triple HB layers and evaluating their optoelectronic performances will be very useful for implementing high-performance BIPV windows.

A simulation and exptl. study on the effect of the buffer layer at the I/P interface on the performance of NIP-type hydrogenated microcryst. silicon (μc-Si:H) single-junction solar cells is presented. Device-quality hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) material as a buffer layer at the I/P interface obviously improves the performance of NIP-type μc-Si:H single-junction solar cells. In addn. to the well-known mechanism that an a-Si:H I/P buffer layer can reduce the recombination c.d. at I/P interfaces, the optically and elec. calibrated simulations and supporting exptl. results in this study illustrate that the performance improvement also originates from the mitigation of the elec. screening effect due to the reduced defect d. at the I/P interfaces, which reinforces the bulk elec. field. Integrating an optimized hydrogen profiling strategy and adding a-Si:H I/P buffer layer yielded an initial efficiency of 9.20% for μc-Si:H single-junction solar cells with an active area of 0.27 cm2. This study may provide new ideas of further improving the performance of NIP-type μc-Si:H single-junction solar cells by mitigating the elec. screening effect. (c) 2015 American Institute of Physics.

The effect of a-Si:H i/p buffer layer on the performance of nc-Si:H solar cells was studied. For thin nc-Si:H cells, an optimized i/p buffer layer decreases the dark current and thus increases the open-circuit voltage. Carrier recombination at the i/p interface is one of the detg. factors for nc-Si:H cell performance, esp. for cells with a thin intrinsic layer. Therefore, optimizing the i/p buffer layer is necessary for achieving high efficiency nc-Si:H solar cells. This interface effect is less pronounced as the nc-Si:H intrinsic layer thickness increases, where the recombination in the bulk becomes a dominant factor. Combining the improved nc-Si:H intrinsic layer with a proper H diln. and an optimized a-Si:H i/p buffer layer, the performance of nc-Si:H single-junction and a-Si:H/a-SiGe:H/nc-Si:H triple-junction cells improves.

Wide-gap non-fullerene acceptor enabling high-performance organic photovoltaic cells for indoor applications
Cui, Yong; Wang, Yuming; Bergqvist, Jonas; Yao, Huifeng; Xu, Ye; Gao, Bowei; Yang, Chenyi; Zhang, Shaoqing; Inganas, Olle; Gao, Feng; Hou, Jianhui

Org. photovoltaic cells are potential candidates to drive low power consumption off-grid electronics for indoor applications. However, their power conversion efficiency is still limited by relatively large losses in the open-circuit voltage and a non-optimal absorption spectrum for indoor illumination. Here, we carefully designed a non-fullerene acceptor named IO-4Cl and blend it with a polymer donor named PBDB-TF to obtain a photoactive layer whose absorption spectrum matches that of indoor light sources. The photovoltaic characterizations reveal a low energy loss below 0.60 eV. As a result, the org. photovoltaic cell (1 cm2) shows a power conversion efficiency of 26.1% with an open-circuit voltage of 1.10 V under a light-emitting diode illumination of 1,000 lx (2,700 K). We also fabricated a large-area cell (4 cm2) through the blade-coating method. Our cell shows an excellent stability, maintaining its initial photovoltaic performance under continuous illumination of the indoor light source for 1,000 h.

Low light illumination study on commercially available homojunction photovoltaic cells
Russo, Johnny; Ray, William, II; Litz, Marc S.
Applied Energy
(
2017
),
191
(

10-21
CODEN:
APENDX
; ISSN:
0306-2619

(
Elsevier Ltd.
)
Low illumination (10-4 suns) and indoor light energy harvesting is needed to meet the demands of zero net energy (ZNE) building, Internet of Things (IoT), and beta-photovoltaic energy harvesting systems to power remote sensors. Photovoltaic (PV) solar cells under low intensity and narrow (±40 nm) light spectrum conditions are not well characterized nor developed, esp. for com. available devices and scalable systems. PV operating characteristics under 1 sun illumination decrease at lower light intensity and narrow spectrum conditions (efficiency drops from ∼25% at 100 mWopt/cm2 to 2% at 1μWopt/cm2). By choosing a PV with a bandgap that matches the light source operating wavelength, the total system efficiency can be improved. By quantifying losses on homojunction photovoltaics (thermalization and leakage current), we have detd. the theor. optimized efficiency for a set of PV material and a selected set of light sources. We measure single-junction solar cells' parameters under three different light sources (indoor light and narrow spectrum LED sources) with light intensities ranging from 0.5 to 100μWopt/cm2. Measurements show that indium gallium phosphide (InGaP) PV has the highest surface power d. and conversion efficiency (29% under ≈1μWopt/cm2 from a 523 nm central peak LED). A beta-photovoltaic exptl. study identifies InGaP to be optimized for use with the ZnS:Cu, Al and tritium at STP. The results have guided the selection of PV material for scalable isotope batteries and other low-light energy harvesting systems.

The field of org. photovoltaics (OPVs) has long focused on matching silicon solar cells, both in high power conversion efficiency (PCE) under solar light and broad absorption of the solar spectrum. We show that OPV devices, which have significantly lower PCEs than high-performing cryst. silicon cells when measured under the typical AM 1.5G solar std., can surpass silicon cells with PCEs >20% measured under LED light. We highlight that the conflation of the terms "solar cell" and "photovoltaic" gives an incomplete view of the potential of many photovoltaic materials, esp. org. materials. By expanding the definition and assessment of photovoltaic devices to include multiple light sources, OPVs-with their higher PCEs under indoor light and qual. benefits of being lightwt., thin, flexible, and semi-transparent-could have a home in previously unconsidered low-power indoor applications.

Solar cell comparison is generally based on an arbitrary max. terrestrial intensity and spectra (of 1 sun, 1000 W/m2) at 25° perpendicular to the cell plane referred to by specialists as AM1.5. In practice, no solar cell experiences such conditions, yet few alternative bases for comparison exist. The interest in this paper is to explore the correct design of indoor Photovoltaic (IPV) products. Given that the indoors, when compared with the outdoors, are characterized by much lower radiant energy intensities, various spectra (including artificial light sources), more general level reports were published, but complete comparison data for indoor conditions are not freely available. Twenty-one different solar cells representing eight different Photovoltaic material technologies are reproducibly elec. characterized under lab. based simulated AM1.5 (1 sun; solar spectrum) from 1000 W/m2 intensity down to the 0.1-1 W/m2 decade. Some were measured under an artificial light source (fluorescent tube) in the 1-10 W/m2 decade. The results are used to validate a phenomenol. based model.

Recently, while increasing research has been focused toward improving the efficiency of various photovoltaic devices under low light intensities, few studies have reported on multi-donor-, multi-acceptor-based bulk heterojunctions (BHJ). In this study, we have demonstrated the utilization of a quaternary BHJ for indoor light energy harvesting applications. We utilized a PCDTBT:PTB7:PC61BM:PC71BM-based BHJ structure in order to improve the morphol., absorption window, and the charge transport properties of the photovoltaic device. The ability of ternary photovoltaics to attain high power-conversion efficiency (PCE) by improving the morphol. and the charge transport properties had already been validated in another study. We show that the advantages of a stable quaternary solar cell can also be achieved with an optimized BHJ compn. ratio of 5:5:3:12, which provides a PCE of 10.6%. Our device showed high shunt resistance and low series resistance, thus facilitating appreciable charge extn. even under low-intensity light conditions such as 500 lx white LED illumination.

An in-depth study on the photovoltaic characteristics under indoor lights, i.e., light-emitting diode (LED), fluorescent lamps, and halogen lamps, was performed with varying the photoactive layer thickness (120-870 nm), by comparing those under 1-sun condition. The semi-cryst. mid-gap photoactive polymer, poly[(2,5-bis(2-hexyldecyloxy)phenylene)-alt-(5,6-difluoro-4,7-di(thiophen-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PPDT2FBT) and a fullerene deriv., [6,6]-Ph C71 butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) were used as a photoactive layer. In the contrary to the measurements under 1-sun condition, the indoor devices show a clearly different behavior, showing the thickness tolerant short-circuit c.d. (JSC) and fill factor (FF) values with 280-870 nm thick photoactive layers. The retained JSC and FF values of thick indoor devices were discussed in terms of the parasitic resistance effects based on the single-diode equiv. circuit model. The much lower series/shunt resistance (Rs/RP) ratio was measured with thick photoactive layer (≥280 nm), resulting in negligible decreases in the JSC and FF values even with a 870-nm-thick active layer under the LED condition. Under 1000 lx LED light, the PPDT2FBT:PC70BM device showed an optimum power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 16% (max power d., 44.8μW/cm2) with an open-circuit voltage of 587 mV, a JSC of 117μA/cm2, and a FF of 65.2. The device with a 870-nm-thick active layer still exhibited an excellent performance with a PCE of 12.5%. These results clearly suggest that the crit. parasitic resistance effects on the performance vary depending on the light illumination condition, and the large RP assocd. with the viable thick photoactive layer and the well-matched absorption (of photoactive layer) with the irradiance spectrum (of indoor light) are essential to realize efficient indoor photovoltaic cells with high JSC and FF.

The objective of this study is to det. the photovoltaic properties of inverted org. photovoltaic devices (OPVs) that employ indium-tin oxide (ITO) modified by ethoxylated polyethylenimine (PEIE) as an electron-collecting electrode under indoor lighting conditions. Owing to the reduced current generation at low light intensity, possessing a sufficiently large shunt resistance (RP) assocd. with a low leakage current is of utmost importance for performance maximization. The photovoltaic properties under this lighting condition were optimized by controlling the thickness of the PEIE layers, and the elec., optical, and surface properties of the PEIE-modified ITO were detd. Inverted OPVs based on poly(3-hexylthiophene)-indene-C60 bisadduct (P3HT-ICBA) with an 8.5-nm-thick PEIE layer yielded a max. power-conversion efficiency (PCE) of 13.9% under an LED light with a luminance of 500 lx. Meanwhile, the same device showed poor performance with a PCE of 3.1% under 1 sun illumination owing to the insulating nature of PEIE.

We synthesized 3 semicryst. polymers (PTTBTBO, PDTBTBO, and P2FDTBTBO) by modulating the intra- and intermol. noncovalent Coulombic interactions and investigated their photovoltaic characteristics under various light intensities. Low series (Rs) and high shunt (Rsh) resistances are essential prerequisites for good device properties under std. illumination (100 mW/cm2). Considering these factors, among 3 polymers, PDTBTBO polymer solar cells (PSCs) exhibited the most desirable characteristics, with peak power conversion efficiencies (PCE) of 7.52 and 9.60% by being blended with PC71BM under std. and dim light (2.5 mW/cm2), resp. P2FDTBTBO PSCs exhibited a low PCE of 3.69% under std. light due to significant charge recombination with high Rs (9.42 Ωcm2). However, the PCE was remarkably improved by 2.3 times (8.33% PCE) under dim light, showing negligible decrease in open-circuit voltage and remarkable increase in fill factor, which is due to an exceptionally high Rsh of over 1000 KΩcm2. Rs is less significant under dim light because the generated current is too small to cause noticeable Rs-induced voltage losses. Instead, high Rsh becomes more important to avoid leakage currents. This work provides important tips to further optimize PSCs for indoor applications with low-power electronic devices such as Internet of things sensors.

Photovoltaic cells are attracting significant interest for harvesting indoor light for low power consumption wireless electronics such as those required for smart homes and offices, and the rapidly-growing Internet of Things. Here, we explore the potential of soln. processable, small mol. photovoltaic cells as indoor power sources. By optimizing the solvent vapor annealing (SVA) time for the photovoltaic layer, a balance between its crystn. and phase sepn. is obtained, resulting in a record power conversion efficiency (PCE) of over 28% under fluorescent lamps of 1000 lx, generating a max. power d. of 78.2 μW cm-2 (>10% PCE under AM1.5G). This high indoor performance surpasses that of silicon based photovoltaic cells, and is similar to that of gallium arsenide photovoltaic cells. Besides, the ratios of the voltage at the max. power point (MPP) to the open circuit voltage are similar from indoor lighting to one sun conditions, which is unique and allows a less power consuming method to track the MPP for a broad range of light intensities (potentially attractive for wearable photovoltaics). New insight into the effect of SVA on the indoor and one sun performance is provided using advanced optoelectronic characterization techniques, which show that the mobility-lifetime products as a function of charge carrier d. can be correlated well with the performance at different light levels. Our results suggest that org. photovoltaic cells could be promising as indoor power sources for self-sustainable electronics.

We used several polymers as the ternary components to demonstrate a ternary strategy to improve the performance of PCDTBT:PC71BM devices under 1 sun and indoor illumination. With a binary bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) of PCDTBT:PC71BM org. photovoltaic (OPV) cell, a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 16.5% under indoor light sources (300 lx from fluorescence tube) was achieved. However, with a ternary BHJ cell of PCDTBT:PDTSTPD:PC71BM, the PCE can be enhanced to 20.8%. FFs are the primarily improved in these devices. Wireless sensor network becomes widespread into home and offices to keep them comfort and save the energy. The battery-less wireless sensor nodes need the high performance indoor solar cells for stable and sustainable operation. Org. Photovoltaics (OPV) has great indoor photovoltaic performance because ultra-thin org. layer has strong absorption against the UV-visible spectrum that is good spectral matching with indoor lightings. In this study, OPV module has 8 cells in series and same size as the conventional amorphous silicon solar cells (a-Si) for indoor light harvesting. OPV and a-Si are measured their photovoltaic performance under the fluorescent light and demonstrated for energy harvester of wireless sensor network. The output power of OPV and a-Si is 43.4 μW cm-2 and 28.5 μW cm-2 at fluorescent light 1000lx resp. The data transmission rate of the wireless sensor node driven by OPV is 30-40% improved under the dim light condition compared to a-Si.

Since their introduction, dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) have achieved huge success at a lab. level. Recently, research is concd. to visualize large DSC modules at the com. platform. We tested structurally simple porphyrin-based dye SK6 and anthracene-based dye CW10 for DSCs application under simulated 1 sun (AM 1.5G) and indoor light sources. These 2 dyes can be easily synthesized and yet are efficient with cell performances of ∼5.42 and ∼5.75% (without coadsorbent/additive) for SK6 and CW10, resp., under AM 1.5G illumination. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of SK6 reported here is the highest ever reported; this is achieved by optimizing the adsorption of SK6 on TiO2 photoanode using the most suitable solvent and immersion period. Cosensitization of SK6 with CW10 on TiO2 surface has boosted cell performance further and achieved PCE of ∼6.31% under AM 1.5G illumination. Charge-transfer properties of individual and cosensitized devices at TiO2/dye/electrolyte interface were examd. via electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. To understand the cell performances under ambient light conditions, we soaked individual and cosensitized devices under T5 and light-emitting diode light sources of 300-6000 lx. The PCE of ∼22.91% under T5 light (6000 lx) with JSC =0.883 mA/cm2, VOC =0.646 V, and FF =0.749 was noted for the cosensitized device, which equals a power output of 426 μW/cm2. These results reveal that DSCs made of structurally simple dyes performed efficiently under both 1 sun (AM 1.5G) and indoor light conditions, which is undoubtedly a significant achievement when it comes to a choice of com. application.

Titanium (Ti) has high potential in many practical applications such as biomedicine, architecture, aviation, and energy. In this study, we demonstrate an innovative application of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) based on Ti photoanodes that can be integrated into the roof engineering of large-scale architectures. A chromatic Ti foil produced by anodizing oxidn. (coloring) technol. is an attractive roof material for large-scale architecture, showing a colorful appearance due to the formation of a reflective TiO2 thin layer on both surfaces of Ti. The DSSC is fabricated on the backside of the chromatic Ti foil using the Ti foil as the working electrode, and this roof-DSSC hybrid configuration can be designed as an energy harvesting device for indoor artificial lighting. Our results show that the facet-textured TiO2 layer on the chromatic Ti foil not only improves the optical reflectance for better light utilization but also effectively suppresses the charge recombination for better electron collection. The power conversion efficiency of the roof-DSSC hybrid system is improved by 30-40% with a main contribution from an improvement of short-circuit c.d. under std. 1 sun and dim-light (600-1000 lx) illumination.
